title.value: Massachusetts, Colorado, California lead Milken Institute Technology & Science Index; new study shows technolgy is still a key driver of regional economic growth

value:
LOS ANGELES - Investments in science and technology - from higher education to industry research and development - are the crucial factors in deciding the fates of regional economies, a new report from the Milken Institute finds.
And according to a comprehensive state-by-state comparison released with the report, Massachusetts, Colorado and California are in the best position to succeed in the technology-led information age.
Despite the dot-com meltdown and the slowdown in the technology sector in the past two years, the study shows that high-tech is as crucial as ever to economic growth.
"The demise of far-fetched Internet businesses hardly refutes the fact that new technology is changing the rules in many sectors of the economy," the report says. "Science, technology and knowledge-driven innovation are critical to job and wealth creation in the new economics of place."
The keys to success, the authors say, are:
o a strong investment in science and technology infrastructure; and
o leveraging those assets for economic development.
The top 10 states in the Science and Technology Index ranking are: (1) Massachusetts, (2) Colorado, (3) California, (4) Maryland, (5) Virginia, (6) Washington, (7) New Jersey, (8) Connecticut, (9) Utah and (10) Minnesota.
The Milken Institute was commissioned by TechVentures Network and the California Technology Trade and Commerce Division of Science Technology and Innovation to develop a series of indicators to measure the performance of California′s high technology-based economy.
In conducting the research, Institute economists found a strong connection between science and technology investment and personal income gains, as well as overall state economic growth. More than three-fourths of personal income growth can be tied to increases in technology output, researchers found.
"What it says to us is that technology is still the most important element in determining regional economic success," says Ross DeVol, Director of Regional and Demographic Studies for the Institute, and author of the report.
The study offers a detailed look at California′s technology position among the other 49 states. While not part of the published report, a separate set of Institute rankings for all 50 states shows the inventory of each state′s technology and science assets.
The states are ranked on 73 separate measurements in five categories: Research & Development Inputs; Risk Capital and Entrepreneurial Infrastructure; Human Capital Investment; Technology and Science Workforce; and Technology Concentration and Dynamism. Individual measurements include everything from the percentage of a state′s population with Ph.D.s to research and development expenditures per capita.
All of these measurements, the Institute found, are important indicators of how well states will do in today′s knowledge-based economy.
"The elements that make a state or a regional economy vibrant and prosperous today are fundamentally different from those of the past," the report says. "State and regional economic performance is determined by how effectively they use their comparative advantages to create and expand knowledge assets and convert them into economic value."
DeVol, who four years ago wrote America′s High-Tech Economy, a groundbreaking report on technology′s influence on metropolitan economies, says the new study points out the critical need for states to invest not only in science and technology, but also to make sure they leverage it.
"You can′t just make investments," DeVol says. "You have to harness them all - the entrepreneurs, the investors, the research, the workers - into real companies with real innovations that can make money. That will foster stronger economic growth and higher-paying jobs."
View a pdf of the report.
In addition to detailed statistics on California′s science and technology assets, all of which are included in the report, the Institute has put together rankings for all 50 states for all 73 measurements as a separate purchase by our online visitors. Media interested in obtaining a copy should contact Skip Rimer, Director of Communications, at (310) 570-4654 or srimer@milkeninstitute.org.
